Award.AwardTitle: Exploring the STEM Engagement of Minority and Women College Students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Directorate of Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences offers postdoctoral research fellowships to provide opportunities for recent doctoral graduates to obtain additional training, to gain research experience under the sponsorship of established scientists, and to broaden their scientific horizons beyond their undergraduate and graduate training. Postdoctoral fellowships are further designed to assist new scientists to direct their research efforts across traditional disciplinary lines and to avail themselves of unique research resources, sites, and facilities, including at foreign locations. This postdoctoral fellowship award supports a rising scholar at the University of California-Davis exploring the STEM engagement of minority and women college students. Currently, women and ethnic minorities are significantly underrepresented in science, technology, engineering and math (STEM) related fields. This underrepresentation is a problem because it can serve as a hindrance to advancements in all areas of STEM. Previous research has started to identify factors both pre- and post-college that may encourage people from underrepresented groups to continue in STEM-related fields. However, we know little about students' day-to-day experiences as they go through the early college years, when many students exit STEM majors. There is reason to expect that diversity in the STEM workforce can lead to innovative solutions to very complex problems. Thus, findings from this project will impact not only emerging scholars in STEM fields, but also future academics, researchers, and STEM employees. This project will broaden the participation of scientists from currently under-represented groups: 1) the project aims directly address the underrepresentation of women and ethnic minorities in the US STEM workforce and identifies solutions to improve this; and 2) during the 2-year fellowship, the principal investigator will engage in mentoring activities to encourage other women and ethnic minorities to become or stay involved in the sciences. As part of the project, study findings will be broadly disseminated to inform and transform existing interventions implemented by various entities within the university community (i.e., dorm administration, student service groups, university administration).

In the United States, women and ethnic minorities continue to be underrepresented in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) areas of study This is despite the fact that women make up slightly more than half of the US population and ethnic minority groups are increasing their representation in the US, including in undergraduate institutions. The proposed study will offer critical insights to share with the university community on ways to increase the numbers of underrepresented groups in STEM, as well as ways to retain them. In the proposed study, 300 college freshmen majoring in a STEM field will be recruited (projected ethnic breakdown based on oversampling are 25% Caucasian, 20% Black/African American, 25% Hispanic/Latino, and 30% Asian descent; 60% women) from a larger study of 1800 college freshmen in order to: 1) explore the daily associations between stereotype threat (feelings of being treated a certain way due to race or ethnicity) experiences and STEM satisfaction, and whether this association strengthens over time; 2) evaluate self-efficacy for STEM field success as a mediator of the association between daily stereotype threats and daily STEM satisfaction; and 3) examine the potential protective role of diversity exposure on continuation in STEM-related fields. To address these aims, the study will use a structural equation model within in a longitudinal framework (four time points across 2 years) with 5-day daily report periods embedded within 3 of those time points.

POR.DRECONTENT:
“Exploring the STEM Engagement of Minority and Women College Students” sought to determine the association over time of daily microaggressions (i.e. daily subtle experience of racism) and satisfaction with choosing a science, technology, engineering, or math (STEM) based major among women and ethnic minorities. It aimed to parse how self-efficacy could serve as a mediator between the daily microaggressions and satisfaction in a STEM major. Then, the study aimed to explore how friend group diversity may serve as a buffer to protect the self-efficacy of ethnic minorities experiencing microaggressions. In addition to daily microaggression analyses, feelings of stereotype threat (i.e. feelings of impending failure because of race and/or gender) were examined longitudinally.

The project specifically examined three aims:

Aim 1. Explore the daily associations between racial microaggressions and STEM major satisfaction and whether this association strengthens over time. 

Aim 2. Evaluate academic self-efficacy as a mediator of the association between daily racial microaggressions and daily satisfaction with STEM major fields. 

Aim 3. Evaluate the potential protective role of daily friend group diversity exposure on major satisfaction.

A cohort of 333 declared STEM majors were recruited out of a larger data collection project tracking the transition from high school to college. This cohort was tracked over their first two years of college through a series of week-long daily surveys given in the winter and spring of their freshmen year (year 1), and fall and winter of their sophomore year (year 2); totaling 20 days of survey collection. Attrition rates averaged 24% across the study with nine students switching out of a STEM-related major within the study time span. The sample was 72% female and consisted of 25% White, 19% LatinX, 47% Asian, and 9% bi-racial or other students.

Overall, it was found that academic self-efficacy mediates the relationship between stereotype threat and major satisfaction across the first two years of college at the aggregate level; however, no mediation effects were found for daily microaggressions. In addition, diversity of friend group was found to be a significant moderator at certain thresholds for stereotype threat over time. 

Specific findings include the following:

Aim 1. No within-person effects were found for experiences of daily microaggressions and major satisfaction, thus there is no significant relationship by day between experiencing a microaggression and reported major satisfaction. However, between-person effects were significant at both the year one spring and year two winter time points. This indicated that on average across those weeks, students who experience more racial microaggressions report lower major satisfaction.

Aim 2. Both racial microaggressions and academic self-efficacy were found to have significant main effects on major satisfaction such that more reported experiences of racial microaggressions in the winter of year one are associated with a decrease in major satisfaction one year later. Higher reported academic self-efficacy at the end of year one was associated with greater major satisfaction in the winter of year two. However, for racial microaggressions, no significant mediation effects were found. When utilizing stereotype threat as the predictor, similar significant main effects were found in addition to a significant mediation effect. Thus, those students reporting higher feelings of stereotype threat are reporting lower major satisfaction via a decrease in academic self-efficacy over a one year period.

Aim 3. Friend group diversity was measured via participants indicating if they had spent time with friends of a different ethnic group each day. Aggregate numbers indicate the number of days per week individuals spent time with a friend of a different ethnicity. This variable was found to moderate the mediation found between stereotype threat and major satisfaction (aim 2) such that those who indicated more days of spending time with a friend of a different ethnicity had a significantly decreased mediation effect (i.e. academic efficacy was less of a factor in lowering major satisfaction). 

Currently, there is a societal concern for the lack of women and ethnic minorities in STEM fields. This lack of diversity within STEM fields can hinder the forward progress of science. Project findings highlight the importance of tracking the retention of minority STEM majors over the course of their college career as opposed to single time point studies. In particular to aim 1, the impact of racial microaggressions appears to be stronger towards the end of the first and second years of college as opposed to the beginning of the school year. This finding may indicate key points for when universities should provide more supports. The addition of academic self-efficacy to the model within aim 2 indicates that there are more than single drivers involved in the reduction of major satisfaction for minority STEM majors. In addition, knowing that friend group diversity can buffer negative impacts of stereotype threat on academic self-efficacy suggests that programs could help students develop diverse social networks as a strategy for STEM major retention.
